H0.text: Which fire-breathing creature of Greek mythology has the head of a lion, body of a goat and the rear of a dragon. Drakon

H1.text: Which fire-breathing creature of Greek mythology has the head of a lion, body of a goat and the rear of a dragon. Typhon

H2.text: Which fire-breathing creature of Greek mythology has the head of a lion, body of a goat and the rear of a dragon. Sphinx

H3.text: Which fire-breathing creature of Greek mythology has the head of a lion, body of a goat and the rear of a dragon. Chim√¶ra

A4.text: Typically, it is depicted as a lion with a goat's head protruding from its back and a tail ending with a snake's head.

A5.text: Homer described the Chimera in the Iliad, saying that 'she was of divine stock not of men, in the fore part a lion, in the hind a serpent, and in the midst a goat, breathing forth in terrible wise the might of blazing fire.'
